g.text: loaded into a 4-neck ﬂask and degassed for 1 h at 120
then purged with Ar gas. OA (1.0 mL) and OAm (1.0 mL)
were injected into the ﬂask, and after completely dissolving the
salt mixture, the temperature was raised to 180
oleate precursor solution (0.8 mL) was swiftly injected into the
reaction ﬂask and then cooled in an ice water bath after 5 s.
Crystallized nanoparticles were precipitated by adding
butyl alcohol (25.0 mL). Alternatively, methyl acetate (25.0
(10 000 rpm using a rotor with a
diameter of 10 cm) for 5 min and then redispersed in toluene.
Subsequently, the NC powder was prepared by drying the
The elemental ratios of the NC
powders were measured using an XRF analyzer (ZSXmini II,
Rigaku). Powder XRD proﬁles were obtained using an X-ray
diﬀractometer (Rint-2200, Rigaku) with a Cu K
source and monochromator. The NC morphologies were
samples were prepared by vacuum drying a drop of a NC
dispersion on carbon-reinforced collodion-coated copper grids
(COL-C10, Oken Shoji) overnight. The EDX was performed
on the same apparatus. FT-IR absorption spectra of the
samples in KBr disks were recorded on an FT-IR spectrometer
vis absorption spectra of the NC
dispersions were measured using an optical absorption
spectrometer (V-570, JASCO). The PL spectra of the NC
dispersions were measured using a ﬂuorescence spectrometer
(FP-6500, JASCO). Each spectral response was calibrated
using an ethylene glycol solution of rhodamine B (5.5 g L
and a standard light source (ESC-333, JASCO). Absolute
PLQYs were measured using a quantum eﬃciency measure-
ment system (QE-2000-311C, Otsuka Electronics). The PL
decay curves were recorded on a ﬂuorescence lifetime
tonics). Herein, the PL decay curves were ﬁtted with the
the PL decay times. The average PL lifetime <
